lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and identify key details about Kim and the animals he sees by choosing correct answers (e.g., matching sentence halves).
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play short sections of the video. Ask: “What did Kim see?” Students match animal pictures to sentence halves.
stretchStrategies: "Wildlife Poster Campaign" – Students create a mini-poster encouraging people to protect a wild animal of their choice. They must include 1–2 sentences (e.g., “This is a fox. It lives in the forest. We must protect it.”).

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say how their lives are similar to or different from the characters in the video.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Draw a chart: “My life / Kim’s life.” Students suggest what’s the same and different using animals and activities.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can discuss why it’s important to learn about wild animals and how we can protect them.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Ask: “Why do we learn about wild animals?” Brainstorm and record answers on the board. Prompt with examples if needed.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.

languageTransferAnalysis.section: 4. Plural forms of it is and there is:
items: Plural forms of these structures do not exist in Vietnamese. It's difficult for kids to remember to produce them, particularly because the plural element comes before the noun phrase. There are two houses
